user_message:
An agent A claimed that the following get_rq_dauth_algo code violates the MISRA C 2023 rule 21.17.
<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17 is Use of the string handling functions from <string.h> shall not result in accesses beyond the bounds of the objects referenced by their pointer parameters.
This rule strictly applies to the Standard Library functions in <string.h> such as memcpy, memmove, memset, memcmp, strcpy, strncpy, strcat, strncat, strlen, and strspn.
</misra_rule>
<target_code>
Here is the original code of get_rq_dauth_algo.
```c
static enum MHD_DigestAuthAlgo3
get_rq_dauth_algo (const struct MHD_RqDAuthParam *const algo_param)
{
  if (NULL == algo_param->value.str)
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5; /* Assume MD5 by default */

  if (algo_param->quoted)
  {
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))

      /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN \
                                               _MHD_SESS_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
    if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n (algo_param->value.str, \
                                               algo_param->value.len, \
                                               _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN))
      return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

    /* No known algorithm has been detected */
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
  }
  /* The algorithm value is not quoted */
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256;

  /* Algorithms below are not supported by MHD for authentication */

  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_MD5_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_MD5_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA256_SESSION;
  if (MHD_str_equal_caseless_s_bin_n_ (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN, \
                                       algo_param->value.str, \
                                       algo_param->value.len))
    return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_SHA512_256_SESSION;

  /* No known algorithm has been detected */
  return MHD_DIGEST_AUTH_ALGO3_INVALID;
}
```
</target_code>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- explanation: your evaluation of the scenario provided by the agent A.
- is_report_correct: whether the report is correct or not (true/false). True means there is a violation.
</response format>
<scenario>
The agent A provided the following violation scenario:
The call passes a string literal formed by macro concatenation (_MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN _MHD_SESS_TOKEN -> "SHA-512-256-sess", length 16) together with algo_param->value.len. If algo_param->value.len is greater than the length of that literal and MHD_str_equal_caseless_quoted_s_bin_n is implemented using a raw memory comparison (e.g. memcmp/strncmp) that reads exactly the provided length from both pointer parameters, the comparison will read past the end of the literal and thus access memory beyond the bounds of the object. Example: algo_param->value.len == 20 causes a memcmp(token_literal, algo_param->value.str, 20) which overruns the 16-byte literal — violating Rule 21.17.
</scenario>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function get_rq_dauth_algo:
#define _MHD_MD5_TOKEN "MD5"
...
#define _MHD_SHA256_TOKEN "SHA-256"
...
#define _MHD_SHA512_256_TOKEN "SHA-512-256"
...
#define _MHD_SESS_TOKEN "-sess"
</additional code>

<instruction>
Judge whether the report is correct or not.
</instruction>
explanation: Agent A’s scenario is plausible but not proven, so the report as stated is not correct as a definitive MISRA 21.17 violation of get_rq_dauth_algo. The code calls helper/comparison functions (MHD_str_equal_caseless_..._bin_n, etc.) rather than calling memcpy/memcmp/strncmp directly. Whether a boundary over-read occurs depends entirely on the implementation of those helper functions. If a helper simply does memcmp(token_literal, algo_param->value.str, algo_param->value.len) (i.e. uses the supplied length without bounding it by the token literal length) then that helper would violate Rule 21.17 (and be buggy) — but the fault would be in the helper, not demonstrably in get_rq_dauth_algo. Conversely, if the helpers compute the token length (or otherwise ensure they only compare up to the token’s bounds) then no violation occurs. Without inspecting the helper implementations, you cannot conclude that get_rq_dauth_algo itself violates MISRA C 2023 Rule 21.17. To resolve this for real, inspect the definitions of the MHD_str_equal... functions or ensure the call site passes an explicit token length (or the helpers use the token length) so no memcmp/strncmp can read past the literal.
